user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericSeek_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GenericSeek_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, int32 offset, uint32 whence)
{
    int                             where;
    off_t                           os_result;
    int32                           retval;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    switch (whence)
    {
        case OS_SEEK_SET:
            where = SEEK_SET;
            break;
        case OS_SEEK_CUR:
            where = SEEK_CUR;
            break;
        case OS_SEEK_END:
            where = SEEK_END;
            break;
        default:
            return OS_ERROR;
    }

    os_result = lseek(impl->fd, (off_t)offset, where);
    if (os_result == (off_t)-1)
    {
        if (errno == ESPIPE)
        {
            /*
             * this means the user tried to seek on a pipe, socket,
             * or other fifo-like handle that doesn't support seeking.
             *
             * Use a different error code to differentiate from an
             * error involving a bad whence/offset
             */
            retval = OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED;
        }
        else
        {
            /*
             * Most likely the "whence" and/or "offset" combo was not valid.
             */
            OS_DEBUG("lseek: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            retval = OS_ERROR;
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * convert value to int32 type for returning to caller.
         * Note that this could potentially overflow an int32
         * for a large file seek.
         */
        retval = (int32)os_result;
    }

    return retval;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_GenericSeek_Impl:
#define OS_SEEK_SET 0
...
#define OS_SEEK_CUR 1
...
#define OS_SEEK_END 2
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_lseek(osal_id_t filedes, int32 offset, uint32 whence)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Make sure the file descriptor is legit before using it */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericSeek_Impl(&token, offset, whence);
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED (-38)
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (os_result == (off_t)-1)
    {
        if (errno == ESPIPE)
        {
            /*
             * this means the user tried to seek on a pipe, socket,
             * or other fifo-like handle that doesn't support seeking.
             *
             * Use a different error code to differentiate from an
             * error involving a bad whence/offset
             */
            retval = OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED;
        }
        else
        {
            /*
             * Most likely the "whence" and/or "offset" combo was not valid.
             */
            OS_DEBUG("lseek: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            retval = OS_ERROR;
        }
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. Both the if (os_result == (off_t)-1) branch and its nested branches are reachable at runtime: when lseek() fails it returns -1 and sets errno; errno == ESPIPE is a real, reachable condition (non-seekable FD), while other errno values lead to the else branch. Therefore there is no unreachable code in the fragment.
